content:
“lass="word-wrap-span">TONIGHT I lass="word-wrap-span">THINK lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats are expecting some lass="word-wrap-span">engagement here—and I expect we’ll get it.” lass="word-wrap-span">That was lass="word-wrap-span">Joe Biden’s opening line in last night's televised debate between ten of the party’s presidential candidates, and he made good on the promise. lass="word-wrap-span">After a sleepy, stammering and unsteady performance in the first primary debates in lass="word-wrap-span">June, Mr Biden, a former vice-president and current front-runner, came prepared to lass="word-wrap-span">fend off attacks. He had been particularly savaged in the previous debate by Kamala lass="word-wrap-span">Harris, a lass="word-wrap-span">California senator who had rebuked his warm recollections of segregationist senators, along with his one-time opposition to mandatory school busing. No such moment materialised in this debate—neither for Ms lass="word-wrap-span">Harris, the only other lass="word-wrap-span">heavyweight to share the stage with him (Bernie lass="word-wrap-span">Sanders, Elizabeth lass="word-wrap-span">Warren and lass="word-wrap-span">Pete lass="word-wrap-span">Buttigieg had all participated in another debate the previous night), nor for any of the eight other candidates, who barely register two percentage points lass="word-wrap-span">apiece.

lass="word-wrap-span">That was not for lack of trying. Mr Biden was attacked often and hard. He and Ms lass="word-wrap-span">Harris tussled at lass="word-wrap-span">The start over lass="word-wrap-span">The wisdom of Medilass="word-wrap-span">Care for lass="word-wrap-span">All, as lass="word-wrap-span">The idea of a single-payer health-lass="word-wrap-span">Care system is known. lass="word-wrap-span">The former vice-president opposes it as a goal; lass="word-wrap-span">The senator embraces it with lass="word-wrap-span">The zeal of a fresh lass="word-wrap-span">convert. Mr Biden’s plan, which would extend lass="word-wrap-span">The framework of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Affordable lass="word-wrap-span">Care lass="word-wrap-span">Act (lass="word-wrap-span">aka Obamalass="word-wrap-span">Care), is judged lass="word-wrap-span">insufficiently progressive by Ms lass="word-wrap-span">Harris; she reckons it would leave 10m lass="word-wrap-span">Americans uninsured. Julián lass="word-wrap-span">Castro, a former housing secretary, attacked lass="word-wrap-span">The front-runner for demurring at his bid to decriminalise illegal immigration. lass="word-wrap-span">That idea has gained currency with remarkable speed among progressively minded lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic candidates. lass="word-wrap-span">Then lass="word-wrap-span">Cory lass="word-wrap-span">Booker, a senator from lass="word-wrap-span">New Jersey, lass="word-wrap-span">assailed Mr Biden for lass="word-wrap-span">The tough-on-crime laws he had supported in lass="word-wrap-span">Congress (“I’m happy you’ve lass="word-wrap-span">evolved, but you’ve offered no redemption to lass="word-wrap-span">The people in prison right now for life”). Kirsten Gillibrand, a lass="word-wrap-span">New York senator, lass="word-wrap-span">dug up an op-ed which Mr Biden had written 40 years ago, to lass="word-wrap-span">imply lass="word-wrap-span">That he had not thought women should join lass="word-wrap-span">The workplace. lass="word-wrap-span">Bill de Blasio, lass="word-wrap-span">The mayor of lass="word-wrap-span">New York lass="word-wrap-span">City, tried to pick fights with Mr Biden over lass="word-wrap-span">deportations and trade. Finlass="word-wrap-span">Ally lass="word-wrap-span">Jay Inslee, Washington state’s governor, damned Mr Biden’s plan to tackle climate change as “middling”.

Mr Biden lass="word-wrap-span">acquitted himself much better than he had last time. lass="word-wrap-span">Some of his answers trailed off, lass="word-wrap-span">And he seemed to stumble over memorised talking points. lass="word-wrap-span">But he was able to lass="word-wrap-span">deflect most of the damage. “lass="word-wrap-span">Thirty trillion dollars has to be paid. lass="word-wrap-span">And I don’t know what math you do in lass="word-wrap-span">New York, I don’t know what math you do in lass="word-wrap-span">California, lass="word-wrap-span">But I tell ya, that’s a lot of money,” he said, parrying lass="word-wrap-span">criticism about his health-care plan by laying into the policies of Ms lass="word-wrap-span">Harris lass="word-wrap-span">And Mr de Blasio. Mr Biden would not be outlass="word-wrap-span">flanked on immigration by Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Castro, who served in Barack Obama’s lass="word-wrap-span">cabinet while he was vice-president, retorting that “I never heard him talk about any of this when he was the secretary”. lass="word-wrap-span">Likewise Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Booker would have to answer for the policing practices in his own city of lass="word-wrap-span">Newark before attacking him. Ms Gillibrlass="word-wrap-span">And’s lass="word-wrap-span">broadsides, lass="word-wrap-span">implying sexism on Mr Biden’s part, llass="word-wrap-span">Anded oddly, given their recently warm working relationship to lass="word-wrap-span">combat rape on college campuses. “I don’t know what’s happened, except that you’re now running for president,” he replied. If it was not a stirring performance, it probably sufficed to stave off another drop in the polls.

It is nonelass="word-wrap-span">Theless striking that Mr Biden’s left lass="word-wrap-span">flank should draw such fire. lass="word-wrap-span">The substance of his platform would have seemed radical just a few years ago. lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">New litmus tests of lass="word-wrap-span">The primary debate—whelass="word-wrap-span">Ther or not candidates profess lass="word-wrap-span">adulation for lass="word-wrap-span">Medicare for lass="word-wrap-span">All or lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Green lass="word-wrap-span">New lass="word-wrap-span">Deal; whelass="word-wrap-span">Ther lass="word-wrap-span">They would decriminalise illegal immigration; and whelass="word-wrap-span">Ther lass="word-wrap-span">They would provide health insurance to those undocumented immigrants—have rapidly become lass="word-wrap-span">benchmarks for defining lass="word-wrap-span">The differences between moderate and progressive. lass="word-wrap-span">The previous night's debate, featuring lass="word-wrap-span">The true-believer progressive lass="word-wrap-span">duo of Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Sanders and Ms lass="word-wrap-span">Warren, lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrated lass="word-wrap-span">The momentum of such thinking within lass="word-wrap-span">The party.

lass="word-wrap-span">There were some strong showings from lass="word-wrap-span">The more marginal class="word-wrap-span">Andidates, though none is lass="word-wrap-span">Likely to have achieved lass="word-wrap-span">The sort of breakout moment needed to qualify for lass="word-wrap-span">The next primary debate. Michael Bennet, an lass="word-wrap-span">astute senator from lass="word-wrap-span">Colorado but an underwhelming orator, may have showed enough spark to attract a second look. (lass="word-wrap-span">Like Mr Biden, his lass="word-wrap-span">instincts tend towards pragmatism on issues lass="word-wrap-span">Like health care lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">impeachment.) lass="word-wrap-span">Andrew lass="word-wrap-span">Yang, an lass="word-wrap-span">entrepreneur from lass="word-wrap-span">New York, was lass="word-wrap-span">cogent lass="word-wrap-span">And displayed a remarkable ability to redirect all questions towards his signature campaign pledge: universal basic income for lass="word-wrap-span">Americans. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Booker, perhaps lass="word-wrap-span">The most naturally gifted speaker on lass="word-wrap-span">The stage, turned in anolass="word-wrap-span">Ther decent performance, though he left little time to explain his own signature policies, beyond “lass="word-wrap-span">The call to unite in common cause lass="word-wrap-span">And common purpose”.

lass="word-wrap-span">Before the next debate, scheduled for lass="word-wrap-span">September 12th in Houston, the lass="word-wrap-span">eligibility requirements for participation are to be raised, in effect winnowing half the field. lass="word-wrap-span">That means lass="word-wrap-span">That the five front-runners from these first four events—kept apart thus far because of debate logistics and television ratings—will at last share a single stage. lass="word-wrap-span">Expect more lass="word-wrap-span">engagement.
